title: [REPOST] Epistemic Learned Helplessness
summary:
Key ideas:
- People lack the basic skill of believing arguments.
- The art of rationality should not aim to make people believe something after it has been proven to them.
- The more educated people are, the less they trust certain ideas.
- Epistemic learned helplessness is a form of protective skepticism that is useful in most cases.

Key learnings:
- It is important to develop critical thinking skills to be able to evaluate arguments.
- Becoming too convinced of an argument without considering opposing views can be dangerous.
- Taking ideas seriously should be the last skill one learns, after learning other skills that allow them to determine which ideas are correct or not.

Key questions:
- How effective are institutes and collaborations in filtering through studies and analyses?
- What are the limitations of epistemic learned helplessness?
- How can we strike a balance between skepticism and taking ideas seriously?
